<snip>If you write the unit tests first (one would presume using JUnit),
what is the value of also stepping through each line of code?</snip>

I guess you're better at writing absolutely complete tests than I am.  It is
not unusual for me to notice boundary conditions while stepping through code
that I failed to notice when I wrote the tests.

How do you write tests that cause a database connection to fail after you
sent the query, but before you got the result back so that the result set
throws an exception?

Donald Holliday

--- "Holliday, Donald B. (LNG-SHEP)" <dhollida@...> wrote:
> <snip>Using a debugger should be the last thing you do to debug a
> module.
> It takes a lot of time.</snip
> 
> Interesting attitude.
> 
> In Code Complete Steve McConnell states "Once a routine compiles, put
> it

Interesting attitude.

In "Extreme Programming Explained", Keny back states "Any program
feature without an automated test simply doesn't exist". If you write
the unit tests first (one would presume using JUnit), what is the value
of also stepping through each line of code? Seriously.

Regards,

Rob
